## Goal: Design a single-message figure


- Start with the claim
- Reduce clutter
  - Simplify gridlines, legends, and redundant labels
- Guide the eye
  - Contrast, hierarchy, and annotation
- Close the loop
  - End with clinical or biological implication



::: footer

:::




## <span style="font-size:80%">Start with the Claim</span> {.smaller}


- Use the title to state the takeaway

- Plot design should visually prove the claim

- Figure is a ‘mini’ scientific argument: visual should include the scientific claim, evidence, and reasoning


::: footer

:::

## <span style="font-size:60%">Start with the Claim</span> {.smaller}


::: columns
::: {.column .small}

Title states the takeaway - reader can glean outcome before even reading the plot

Plot design visually proves the claim - downward slope of the line visually confirms the claim of improvement

Mini scientific argument:

  - **Claim**: Glucose levels decrease after therapy
  - **Evidence**: Consistent downward pattern in the data
  - **Reasoning**: Lower glucose $\rightarrow$ improved metabolic control $\rightarrow$ a biologically meaningful effect


:::
::: column

```{r}
#| fig-width: 8
#| fig-height: 9

# Start with claim
library(tidyverse)
set.seed(1)

weeks <- 0:12
df <- tibble(
  week = weeks,
  glucose = 165 - 3.2 * week + rnorm(length(weeks), 0, 6)
)

ggplot(df, aes(week, glucose)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(
    title = "Average Fasting Glucose Falls After 12 Weeks of Therapy",
    subtitle = "Change anchored at treatment initiation (Week 0 baseline)",
    x = "Weeks since therapy start", y = "Mean fasting glucose (mg/dL)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 12) +
  theme(panel.grid.minor = element_blank())


```
:::
:::

## <span style="font-size:80%">Reduce clutter: simplify focus</span> {.smaller}

**Goal**: remove redundant or competing visual elements - help the viewer see the scientific signal

**Simplify the visual field**: focus on the message

**Remove redundant legends and labels**: if color, annotation, or axis titles already explain meaning, a legend adds redundancy

**Soften or remove unnecessary gridlines**: subtle scaffolding often enhances perception more than overstructure

**Use whitespace as structure**: adequate spacing between groups, axes, and annotations separates concepts more effectively than lines or boxes


::: footer

:::

## <span style="font-size:60%">Reduce clutter: simplify focus</span> {.smaller}


::: columns
::: {.column .small}

**Interpretation***:

*Green line*: average HbA1c (%) over 16 weeks following therapy initiation

*Dotted horizontal line*: marks the clinical target threshold of 7% [Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) for adequate glycemic control]

Clinically meaningful response to therapy: HbA1c decreasing from roughly 8.3% to near 7% 

Controlled, safe improvement



:::
::: column

```{r}
#| fig-width: 8
#| fig-height: 9
# Reduce Clutter
library(tidyverse)
set.seed(1)
wk <- 0:16
a1c <- tibble(
  week = wk,
  HbA1c = 8.3 - 0.1 * wk + rnorm(length(wk), 0, 0.08)
)

ggplot(a1c, aes(week, HbA1c)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1.1, color = "#1B9E77") +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 7, linetype = "dotted") +
  labs(
    title = "HbA1c Gradually Declines Toward Clinical Goal",
    x = "Weeks since therapy start", y = "HbA1c (%)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 12) +
  theme(
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
    legend.position = "none"
)

```
:::
:::

## <span style="font-size:80%">Guide the eye: hierarchy & annotation</span> {.smaller}

Captions within figures should help tell the story

- Text annotations reinforce interpretation

Annotations and arrows explain the “why” behind the shape of the plot

- Arrows and short text labels translate pattern into meaning

Color, size, and weight signal importance

- not every data element deserves equal visual emphasis

- use color contrast to distinguish key findings (e.g., highlight the therapeutic threshold or responder group)



::: footer

:::

## <span style="font-size:60%">Guide the eye: hierarchy & annotation</span> {.smaller}


::: columns
::: {.column .small}

**Research Question**:

When does HbA1c reach the clinical control threshold [7% HbA1c]?

**Plot Type**:
Annotated line plot with directed arrow and label

**Rationale**:
Guided hierarchy ensures the eye lands first on the crossing point [the biological event of interest]




:::
::: column

```{r}
#| fig-width: 8
#| fig-height: 9
# Guide the Eye
library(tidyverse)
set.seed(1)
wk <- 0:16
a1c <- tibble(
  week = wk,
  HbA1c = 8.4 - 0.12 * wk + rnorm(length(wk), 0, 0.08)
)

cross <- a1c$week[min(which(a1c$HbA1c <= 7))]

ggplot(a1c, aes(week, HbA1c)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1.1, color = "#4B9CD3") +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 7, linetype = "dotted") +
  annotate("segment", x = cross, xend = cross, y = 7.4, yend = 7.05,
           arrow = arrow(length = unit(0.12, "in"))) +
  annotate("text", x = cross + 0.5, y = 7.45,
           label = "Threshold reached \n(≤7%)", hjust = 0) +
  labs(
    title = "HbA1c Crosses Clinical Target Around Week 12",
    subtitle = "Arrow and annotation guide the viewer to key biological moment",
    x = "Weeks since therapy start", y = "HbA1c (%)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 12)

```
:::
:::

## <span style="font-size:60%">Guide the eye: hierarchy & annotation</span> {.smaller}


::: columns
::: {.column .small}

**Plot Interpretation**:

*Blue Line*: average HbA1c trajectory for a cohort of patients following therapy initiation

*Dotted horizontal line*: ADA clinical target for good glycemic control

*Arrow and label*: week where the average HbA1c value first falls below this threshold

**Scientific Interpretation**:

Indicates clinically meaningful response to therapy 

Cohort, on average, achieves recommended glycemic control by week 12

Sustained downward trend : effective and durable treatment response

Annotated arrow: guides the eye to the key biological event - time point noting when the therapeutic goal is met

:::
::: column

```{r}
#| fig-width: 8
#| fig-height: 9
# Guide the Eye
library(tidyverse)
set.seed(1)
wk <- 0:16
a1c <- tibble(
  week = wk,
  HbA1c = 8.4 - 0.12 * wk + rnorm(length(wk), 0, 0.08)
)

cross <- a1c$week[min(which(a1c$HbA1c <= 7))]

ggplot(a1c, aes(week, HbA1c)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1.1, color = "#4B9CD3") +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 7, linetype = "dotted") +
  annotate("segment", x = cross, xend = cross, y = 7.4, yend = 7.05,
           arrow = arrow(length = unit(0.12, "in"))) +
  annotate("text", x = cross + 0.5, y = 7.45,
           label = "Threshold reached \n(≤7%)", hjust = 0) +
  labs(
    title = "HbA1c Crosses Clinical Target Around Week 12",
    subtitle = "Arrow and annotation guide the viewer to key biological moment",
    x = "Weeks since therapy start", y = "HbA1c (%)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 12)
```

## <span style="font-size:80%">Close the Loop: Connect Data to Biology</span> {.smaller}

End every visualization by connecting quantitative findings back to biological or clinical insight

Visual summaries should reinforce biomedical and clinical thinking

**Connect measurement to meaning**: data trends are valuable only if interpreted in context

**Annotate the Implication**: annotations guide interpretation without requiring a separate discussion section


::: footer
:::

## <span style="font-size:80%"></span> {.smaller}

Figure should capture the following:

**Observation**: What happened numerically?

**Pattern**: What is the shape or trajectory?

**Meaning**: What biological process does it represent?

**Implication**: What consequence does it carry for health or treatment?

::: footer
:::

## <span style="font-size:60%">Close the Loop: Connect Data to Biology</span> {.smaller}


::: columns
::: {.column .small}

**Research Question**

How does the cohort-level fasting glucose evolve after therapy, and when does the typical patient (median) enter the clinically safer range?

**Plot Type**:

Smoothed mean line with 95% variability ribbon and clinical reference line

**Reason for Selecting This Plot**

- Start with the claim: Title states the clinical takeaway
- Reduce clutter: Minimal gridlines
- Guide the eye: Contrast (bold median vs faint ribbon), one arrow + label at the crossing
- Close the loop: Subtitle ties the visual to the biological/clinical implication (below 126 mg/dL = improved control)

:::
::: column

```{r}
#| fig-width: 8
#| fig-height: 9
# Close the Loop
library(tidyverse)
set.seed(1)

# Simulate population mean + 95% range for fasting glucose over time
weeks <- 0:12
df <- tibble(
  week = weeks,
  mean_glucose = 165 - 3.2 * week + rnorm(length(weeks), 0, 4),
  sd_glucose   = 10 + 1.2 * exp(-0.2 * week)
)

ggplot(df, aes(week, mean_glucose)) +
  # light ribbon for variability band (not every patient)
  geom_ribbon(aes(ymin = mean_glucose - sd_glucose,
                  ymax = mean_glucose + sd_glucose),
              fill = "grey85", alpha = 0.4) +
  # bold mean trajectory
  geom_line(linewidth = 1.3, color = "#1B2838") +
  # clinical reference line
  geom_hline(yintercept = 126, linetype = "dashed", color = "#D55E00") +
  # concise annotation: tie data → clinical meaning
  annotate("text", x = 8, y = 128,
           label = "Safe fasting range \n(≤126 mg/dL)",
           hjust = 0, vjust = -0.5, size = 3.8, color = "#D55E00") +
  labs(
    title = "Cohort Mean Glucose Declines Into the Safe Range",
        subtitle = "Clinical implication: moving below the diabetes diagnostic threshold \nindicates improved glycemic control",
    x = "Weeks since therapy start", y = "Fasting glucose (mg/dL)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13) +
  theme(
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    legend.position = "none"
  )



```
:::
:::

## <span style="font-size:60%">Close the Loop: Connect Data to Biology</span> {.smaller}


::: columns
::: {.column .small}

**Interpretation**

Median fasting glucose steadily declines after therapy begins, showing a consistent treatment response across the cohort

Interquartile range (IQR) [grey band] :  patient variability

Clinical threshold: diagnostic boundary between diabetes and normal fasting glucose - dashed horizontal line [126 mg/dL]

Population’s median fasting glucose returns to a clinically safer range

:::
::: column

```{r}

#| fig-height: 9

  # light ribbon for variability band (not every patient)

                  ymax = mean_glucose + sd_glucose),
              fill = "grey85", alpha = 0.4) +

  geom_line(linewidth = 1.3, color = "#1B2838") +
  # clinical reference line
  geom_hline(yintercept = 126, linetype = "dashed", color = "#D55E00") +
  # concise annotation: tie data → clinical meaning
  annotate("text", x = 8, y = 128,
           label = "Safe fasting range \n(≤126 mg/dL)",
           hjust = 0, vjust = -0.5, size = 3.8, color = "#D55E00") +
  labs(
    title = "Cohort Mean Glucose Declines Into the Safe Range",
        subtitle = "Clinical implication: moving below the diabetes diagnostic threshold \nindicates improved glycemic control",
    x = "Weeks since therapy start", y = "Fasting glucose (mg/dL)"
```

## <span style="font-size:80%">Summary</span> {.smaller}

Communicating quantitative insight:

Start with the 

- Figure should begin with a clear, declarative statement of what the data show
- Scientific claim made visible: titles, axes, and visual emphasis should reinforce a single takeaway

Reduce Clutter
- simplify design to spotlight the core message

::: footer
:::



## <span style="font-size:80%">Summary</span> {.smaller}

Communicating quantitative insight:

Guide the Eye
- Use visual hierarchy (contrast, color, weight) and annotation (arrows, labels) to direct interpretation

Close the Loop
- Connect numeric trends back to biological or clinical meaning

::: footer
:::
